awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Accelerated Design and Deployment of Metal Alloy Surfaces for Chemoresponsive Liquid Crystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: This project seeks to accelerate the discovery and deployment of chemically-responsive materials, based on liquid crystals interfaced with metal surfaces, that are capable of generating optical outputs when exposed to targeted small (gas phase) molecules. The class of liquid crystalline materials to be developed in this project have high technological potential due to their ability to sense specific organic molecules of importance to a range of chemical industries, law enforcement, defense, and medicine. Prior efforts to develop this class of materials were hampered by the need to perform large numbers of laborious experiments. In contrast, the methodology to be advanced in this project will use iterative cycles of electronic structure computations, syntheses of new molecules and advanced materials characterization to improve all three aspects of the approach, and thus accelerate the realization of chemically-responsive liquid crystals. More broadly, the project will contribute the training of a next generation workforce versed in a new, accelerated materials deployment paradigm for rapid design and development of functional materials. The transdisciplinary team of investigators leading the project will develop new instructional materials as well as new programs for public outreach efforts and engagement of underrepresented groups. The team leaders have a record of entrepreneurism, and students and postdoctoral fellows engaged in this project will be mentored in entrepreneurial approaches to technology deployment.

Technical Description: This project aims to move chemoresponsive liquid crystals (CLCs) along the materials development continuum by focusing on industrially important analytes (e.g., NO, Cl2 and ClO2) that bind weakly to metal cations and thus cannot be detected through use of previous CLC designs. Specifically, through iterative improvement of electronic structure calculations, organic synthesis, and thermophysical property measurements, the team seeks to develop an exciting new class of CLCs based on interactions of liquid crystals with tailored metal and alloy surfaces. A key aspect of this project is that it aims to exploit a convergence of ideas from the surface science and catalysis communities, which have extensively studied metals and alloys, and the soft matter community, which has not, to create new classes of stimuli-response materials. Feedback into the surface science community on the effects of organic ligands on metal and alloy surface properties is anticipated. The work will also advance synthetic methodology leading to functional organic mesogens that possess tailored interactions at metal and alloy interfaces. The efforts of the team will be integrated by data management that interfaces to US national databases, thus contributing to national infrastructure by promoting access to data and metadata for the scientific and industrial community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project led to important advances in methodology for the accelerated design of chemically-responsive (chemoresponsive) liquid crystals (LCs), achieved via close integration of cycles of computational prediction (Mavrikakis), synthesis of new mesogens (Twieg), and experimental characterization (Abbott).  These efforts were informed by fundamental knowledge related to surface science and catalysis.  One set of new designs of chemoresponsive LCs realized by this DMREF team employed elementary surface reactions on metal and metal alloy surfaces that involved atomic displacement events.  Electronic structure calculations of displacement events guided our designs of mesogens with tailored interactions with the metal surfaces. An illustrative example of this design was a LC system that detected NO2, a gaseous air pollutant known to have harmful effects on the human respiratory system. The design was based on displacement events on the surfaces of coinage metals (Au, Ag and Cu).  A second set of designs developed by our DMREF team used computationally predicted thermochemical pathways of complex catalytic reactions as the basis of chemoresponsive LC systems.  These efforts built from a deep understanding of a two-stage LC response identified by our DMREF team. The two stage LC response reflected sequential reactions on Pd surfaces, the first reaction being dissociation of H2, and the second being a hydrogenation reaction that involved the mesogen. Key examples explored by our team included sequential hydrogenation of alkyne-terminated LCs on bimetallic Pd-Au surfaces, and hydrogenation of NO2-terminated LCs on Pd surfaces.  An additional important topic addressed by our DMREF team involved the influence of chemical adsorbates on the atomic-scale organization of metal alloy surfaces. Specifically, experiments and computations were performed to elucidate how the organization of the Pd atoms on Au surfaces change as a function of the presence and types of adsorbates (H, CO, O), thus providing insight into how the atomic-scale reorganization of surfaces impacts the chemoresponsiveness of LCs.

In addition, the project provided a rich opportunity to train the next generation of scientists and engineers in methodologies for accelerated materials design.  The entire DMREF team (including the three senior investigators) met via Zoom every three weeks and, additionally, frequent emails and phone calls between team members led to a constant exchange of ideas between computation, synthesis and characterization efforts.  The environment was an exemplary one for the interdisciplinary training of students, and it also provided a context for public outreach efforts that conveyed how computational methods are advancing materials design. Overall, the accomplishments of this DMREF team provide compelling evidence of the upside potential of convergent research at the intersection of catalysis and soft materials, and its potential to create new classes of chemoresponsive materials for next-generation chemical sensors and soft actuators as needed for personalized healthcare, environmental monitoring and an advanced chemical industry.
